review.title: Revisable Justified Belief: Preliminary Report
review.abstract: The theory $\mathsf{CDL}$ of Conditional Doxastic Logic is the single-agent version of Board's multi-agent theory $\mathsf{BRSIC}$ of conditional belief. $\mathsf{CDL}$ may be viewed as a version of AGM belief revision theory in which Boolean combinations of revisions are expressible in the language. We introduce a theory $\mathsf{JCDL}$ of Justified Conditional Doxastic Logic that replaces conditional belief formulas $B^\psi\varphi$ by expressions $t{\,:^{\psi}}\varphi$ made up of a term $t$ whose syntactic structure suggests a derivation of the belief $\varphi$ after revision by $\psi$. This allows us to think of terms $t$ as reasons justifying a belief in various formulas after a revision takes place. We show that $\mathsf{JCDL}$-theorems are the exact analogs of $\mathsf{CDL}$-theorems, and that this result holds the other way around as well. This allows us to think of $\mathsf{JCDL}$ as a theory of revisable justified belief.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Since JCDL is a principled analogy to CDL (according to Theorem 5.9), we are led to the following proposal: JCDL is a version of the general assembly revision, in which Boolean combinations of reasonable revisions can be expressed in language. Essentially, a formula that is part of the faith state after a revision by it could be substantiated by a specific reason whose syntactic structure traces the emergence of "incremental" basic principles, suggesting that we consider JCDL as a theory of revisable justified faith. It would be interesting to see if there is any explicit version of the general assembly revision principles that agrees with JCDL in the way that the standard general assembly revision agrees with CDL.
